participants.participant: Malcolm Gilbert, Head of Investor Relations & Rating Agencies
James J. Schiro, Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I think we are ready to start now. And welcome to Zurich's Half Year 2009 Results Presentation. Can you please make sure if you are in the room, you have your phones switched off? And I would refer you to the Slide Two, the disclaimer cautionary statement.
Today we have CEO, James Schiro; CFO, Dieter Wemmer, who will take you through the results and then we will have the Q&A after both presentations. So without further ado, I hand over to Jim.

Thanks, Malcolm. Welcome to Zurich's half year 2009 results announcement. I am pleased to report an outstanding set of operating results. Amidst some of the most volatile markets anyone has experienced, we are effectively managing our way through this crisis, positioning ourselves to enter the recovery period from a position of strength.

But as we look at the second quarter results, let me remind you that that recent upturn of the capital markets only brings us to the year-end 2008 levels. It does not bring us back to the pre-crisis financial market valuations or the pre-crisis consumer confidence levels.

This is an important reality to keep in mind. It underscores why we believe these are such outstanding results. Since the financial crisis began in earnest in the latter half of 2008, all sectors of the global economy have struggled with the business and financial implications of the greatest economic dislocations in a generation. For insurers, those impacts have been most acutely felt through reduced investment earnings, slower economic activity and cautious customer behaviors.

Over the past several quarters, Zurich too has been impacted with our $185 billion investment portfolio suffering impairments and our tens of millions of customers feeling the effects of the recession, some more acutely than others. But by leveraging the execution culture embodied through the Zurich Way, we are reacted to proactively manage those factors that were within our control, ranging from our risk tolerance and investment exposures to our expense base and product portfolio. As a result, I'm proud to announce our 26th straight quarter of profitability and our third consecutive quarter of increased profitability.

Net income for the six months was 1.3 billion, of which, close to 900 million was generated in the second quarter alone, nearly 150% increase over the first quarter's earnings. Similarly, business operating profit for the first half was 2.6 billion, 1.5 billion of which was earned in the second quarter, representing a 46% increase over the first quarter.

Based on the strengths of these results, we continue to meet our mid-term target, generating a 16.6% business operating profit post-tax return. Furthermore, despite the ongoing financial pressure, we increased our shareholder's equity by 14% and strengthened our Solvency 1 ratio to 180%, showing the value of a sophisticated and transparent approach to capital management.

Our ability to achieve such strong results is rooted in the disciplined approach we take to operational and financial issues and our commitment to control those factors of success that are within our ability to influence.

On the rates we charge, it means we have systematically gone about making the price of risk more transparent to our customers, refusing to chase volume at the expense of profitability. As a result, we are seeing continued and widespread improvements in rates, from a 1% improvement in the fourth quarter to a 2% in the first quarter, to a 4% in the most recent quarter. These results are a testament to our success and lead the market efforts and directly reflect the disciplined approach we take to putting risks on our book.

On the products we sell, to which customers. It means our global life business continued to shift its focus towards more protection business, while accelerating growth in its banking distribution and other significant pillars. Both APE and new business values are up in local currencies and with a new business margin holding at a solid 21%.

And how we invest the revenues on the business generated. It means our strict approach to managing assets relative to liabilities on a risk-adjusted basis, maintained its long-term view on asset allocations, generating a non-annualized 1.6% total investment return.

Last, on how we manage our operating cost. Controlling what we can influence means that we remain well on target to achieve both our 900 million Zurich Way improvement target and the 400 million expense reductions target, illustrating just how valuable operating efficiency can prove in challenging markets. In fact, despite the defensive nature of some of our tactical responses to the crisis, we continue to capitalize proactively on market opportunities that emerge, positioning us well for when, not if, economic activity returns to pre-crisis levels.

For example, our integration of AIG's personal auto group is in line with our plans and when done, will propel Farmers into the leading ranks of the direct auto market and solidify its position as the third largest personal lines insurer in America.

However, we have also been making other investments in long-term sustainable growth, driving the Zurich HelpPoint concept deeper into our proposition development processes, improving our capabilities to deliver on our customers needs and broadening our product range.

None of these action steps or financial achievements would be possible, however, without the motivation and commitment of 60,000 Zurich employees around the world. It is a testament to their effectiveness that we entered this financial crisis with the fundamentals intact and with the institutional means to respond and adapt the prevailing market conditions. Their immense capabilities are also evident in the series of internal appointments we have announced recently in the U.S., Europe, South Africa and elsewhere, illustrating the depth of our bench strength and the success of our ongoing talent management efforts.

Needless to say, I'm proud of these results, and the efforts our people undertook to make them possible. I'm also confident in our ability to continually proactively manage our through this financial crisis in a manner that will deliver strong results, while positioning us to enter the recovery period from our position of strength.

To achieve this, we will continue to pursue operational transformation as we enter the second and third waves of our target operating model initiative. We will continue to exercise a disciplined approach to rates, balancing the needs of our customers with the economics of risk. And we will continue to pursue opportunities for growth, both organic and through acquisitions, if they meet our strict financial and strategic targets.

There is no question, these are certainly challenging times and Zurich has not been immune from the pressures of this marketplace. But we entered this crisis prepared. And I'm confident that we will exit it even stronger.
And now to give you a more detailed review of these financial results, I hand it over to our Chief Financial Officer, Dieter Wemmer.
So thank you, Jim, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. As Jim has said, looking at our overall results and year-on-year comparison does not put our half year 2009 results into the proper context.

The simple picture which the first slide illustrates is the steady recovery of the operating profit and net income over the last three quarters from the effect of the financial markets. Even in the weakest quarter, we made profit and although the numbers dropped, at no time was integrity of the Group capital or solvency position threatened. This, as we have said before, is not a lucky accident. Our balance approach to the business and to risk management and our diversification of risk has paid off in this stressed situation.

We don't assume we are at the end of the crisis and continue to manage the risk profile of the Group carefully. However, the improving markets through the second quarter and into July continue to further consolidate the position.

The other theme I will refer to as we go through the numbers as the resilience of the operating business. In fact, a number of areas are showing signs of improving results from recent quarters independent of financial market volatility. In addition, we are well on track to achieve our 2009 Zurich Way targets and actions have been taken to achieve additional expense reduction of at least $400 million during 2009. So the effect of this is beginning to show through in the expense base of all our operating segments.

So we are pleased to have announced another solid operating performance with business operating profit for the quarter of $1.5 billion and once again, business operating profit after tax ROE over our 16% mid-term target. The underlying strength of the operating profit can be seen on the next slide.

The core operating businesses achieved a BOP of just over $2.8 billion, down 19% from half year last year. This is mainly driven by currency effects, accounting for six percentage points, financial market impact, accounting for about two percentage points, as well as lower investment income, particularly in our general insurance segment, which suffers more from falling interest rates at the short end of the interest curve. So non-core business was again where the financial market impact most affected the operating profit.

I will now go through the detail by segment of the operating results, starting as usually with our top-line on Page Nine. We continue to achieve profitable growth in selected areas of business, but have seen top-line reductions in some areas where levels of insured exposures were down due to the economic environment or where we lost business, when we were not able to achieve the rates necessary to maintain our margins.

For general insurance, gross-written premium decreased by only 2% in local currency, due to a small increase in the second quarter following a 3% reduction in the first quarter. Global Corporate and International markets achieved local currency growth, while Europe General Insurance is largely flat.

However, during the second quarter, our top-line in Europe started to be impacted by the economic downturn. For example, this manifested itself in Personal Lines motor in the U.K. and Spain. In North America Commercial, we are continuing to manage for margin in an environment with falling levels of insured customers' exposures.

Again, the second quarter showed a recovery compared with the first quarter. Gross written premium reduced by 10% for North America Commercial in the six months, with the second quarter being down less than 7% compared to 14% in the first quarter, this in spite of the continuing effects of lower economic activity, mostly in the automotive and construction industry which we talked about in the first quarter.

Turning to Global Life, new business volume grew by 19% in local currency, a good result in the challenging financial markets. The business acquired in Spain in the third quarter 2008 contributed $390 million, representing 20% of our new business in the first six months. This combined with growth in market share helped to offset the general decline in many markets. Additionally, the net policyholder cash flow further increased during the second quarter and now exceeds positive 1.5 billion inflow year-to-date. You can find details on this on Page 43 of the appendix.

Farmers Management Services saw also growth in fees of 4%. This was driven by premium growth at the exchanges largely supported by the transfer of the small business portfolio from North America Commercial starting a year ago. Farmers Re gross-written premium has increased as the Quota Share reinsurance treaty with the exchanges, as already reported, was increased from five to 25% in September last year and then following to 37.5% from June 30 on.

Let's move on to look at the general insurance segment in more detail on Slide 10 with the rate change monitor. I am very happy to tell you that overall, our general insurance rates continued the upward trend observed in the last couple of quarters. Year-to-date, average rates are 3% up for the segment, as a result of a discreet quarter improvement of over 4% compared to 2% in the first quarter and 1% in the last quarter of 2008.

These improvements are the direct result of our lead markets initiative, launched late last year. Our approach to rate increase is a differentiated one, responding to individual risk characteristics and is based on underwriting and pricing discipline rather than on volume management.

This holds true not only for our renewed business reflected in the rate change monitor, but equally so for our new business, where we apply the same pricing methodologies based on technical price. We have observed that's a main focus and the commercial market appears to be on renewal rates, while the approach to new business pricing seems to be a less disciplined in the industry in general.

Starting with Global Corporate, the overall rates are up by over 5%. As expected, our North American unit is leading the way with 9% increases, but equally encouraging in the U.K. result, where rates are up by 7%. So that's a view of global corporate, it's up 2%, but this is in marketplaces where earlier year's reduction were much less pronounced.

In North America Commercial, we have achieved higher rate increases compare to earlier quarters, in spite of the continuing pressure from the economic environment. Year-to-date rates are up by 3%, a clear improvement to the 2% in the first quarter. And our European personal lines see overall increase of 2% is driven by the U.K., with Spain and Italy improving on the first quarter performance. In our Commercial business there, the rate increases continue to be around 2%. In international market, the change in commercial line rates is mostly attributable to the Australian unit, where we continue to push for improvement started last year.

Let's now turn to Slide 11, to dive into our General Insurance key performance indicators. General Insurance continues to deliver strong operating results, with the net underwriting results mostly flat in local currency. The business operating profit decreased by 23% year-on-year or 16% in local currency. As I said before, this reduction is driven by the investment income but also by non-technical result. A small amount arises from the effect in yield from reinvested assets and assets invested in the period. Also, we have seen a step change in investment income due to the $1.3 billion repatriation of capital from the U.K. to the group and lower returns from repo activities.

Expressed in local currency and net of the effect of repos, the investment income explains roughly half of the drop in business operating profit and the non-technical result largely explains the remaining balance. The non-technical result is always driven by non-recurring items, which will always show some volatility. In 2008, we experienced a significant number of positive items whereas in 2009, our experience so far has been less favorable.

In total, the combined ratio was flat year-on-year at 96.2%, with North America Commercial largely flat and Global Corporate improving significantly, the latter due to much a lower share of large and mid-size losses compared to 2008. In international market, we experienced the opposite with a higher proportional of large losses in Mexico and Australia, the latter due to the bush fires earlier this year.

Also offsetting the improvement in Global Corporate was Europe General Insurance where we, apart from higher large losses, also experienced a deterioration in our motor portfolio in Italy. As you know, there is a market-wide issue in Italy that is mainly due to a court decision on bodily injury compensation levels, changes in the regulation which impacting rating schemes and the reporting pattern of claims.

As mentioned in May, we are addressing the situation. We have strengthened the local management team. We are improving our risk selection process and we have started to increase rates, both on April 1 and July 1.

Moving on, I will now go into more detail around the expense ratio development. The expense ratio is flat year-on-year, at the same time as we continue to invest in operational transformation and profitable growth.

As you can see from the graph, the increase in the commission ratio is compensated by lower premium tax and improvement in our managed expenses. The commission ratio increased by 0.4 percentage points, mainly as a result of change in business mix.

Business mix is also the major reason for the 0.2 percentage point reduction in premium taxes. Our other underwriting expenses ratio reduced by 20 basis points and the driver include a total head count reduction in General Insurance by 1,500 people since the beginning of year, equivalent to 4%. Our 2009 expense saving initiative of a General Insurance target around 60% which are starting to show. This is evident when looking at this item, other underwriting expenses, which improved compared to the first quarter.

Now let's have a more – closer look to the loss ratio. The overall half year loss ratio for General Insurance is largely unchanged, as is the underlying loss ratio. This result is very much encouraging, since we expect higher rate levels to continue to come through in the upcoming quarters.

Moving on to the details, the large losses are around 300 million lower this year. As I mentioned, since it's driven by Global Corporate, where the large loss experience returned to more normal levels, after seeing a higher frequency of large losses in the first six months in 2008.

North America Commercial also experienced lower large losses. Offsetting this are the prior year reserve releases, which are lower year-on-year. As you know, this component is made up of a large number of movements across all our units. Our reserving policy remains unchanged and the variation of $114 million in first quarter and 281 million in the second quarter is simply a normal variation of the numbers for a large reserve portfolios like ours.

With that, it's now time to look at our reinsurance program on Slide 14. As you all know, the Atlantic hurricane season officially started on June 1 and therefore, I will give you an update on our reinsurance protection for major catastrophes. The structure is made up by three independent towers of regional catastrophic covers, the U.S., Europe and rest of the world.

We buy our reinsurance on an economic basis and the primary aim is to protect our balance sheet and solvency. The regions have similar structures and coverage, but the limits vary in accordance to the economic risks for each region.

As you can see on this slide, Europe has the largest individual cover which represents the fact that our largest CAT exposure is still European windstorm. It is worth pointing out that in the U.S. and European tower, Zurich retains part of the risk to its co-participation. The co-participation varies depending on layer, but on average, Zurich's share is 19% of the U.S. treaty and 15% of the European Tower.

A final clarification worth making is around a new component of our catastrophe cover. This year, we have agreed to a risk swap with a major Japanese carrier. We have assumed the risk of a $100 million cover for a Japanese typhoon. In exchange, we receive a corresponding cover for U.S. windstorm. The reasons behind the swap are that reinsurance capacity has become scarcer, cover more expensive and reinsurer counterparty risk has increased since last year. Through the diversification benefit achieved by swapping a peak risk for a non-peak risk, this is economically very attractive to both us and our counterparty.

This concludes the General Insurance part and we can now move to have a look at our Life business. As I mentioned before, new business growth of 19% in local currency reflects the volumes from the businesses acquired last year in Spain. In total, on a like-on-like comparison, the annual premium equivalent volume was flat year-on-year in a difficult market environment.

By country, we are particularly pleased with the performance in Ireland, where we saw a flight to quality and grew 3% in local currencies in a market that has declined over 40%, ensuring obviously further gains in market share. We also saw growth in Latin America, balancing challenges in emerging markets and Asia.

The new business margin at 21% overall remained at our target level. We are increasing our focus on protection and long-term savings in response to changing market conditions. Obviously the lower interest rates impacted the profitability of guaranteed savings products in Germany and Switzerland.

The strength of the Zurich brand allowed us to maintain our premium rates while building market share. This combined with the strong expense control allowed us to keep our profitability high. In addition, Global Life is benefiting from cost reductions in several areas including headcounts and discretionary spending.

The growth and sustained margin resulted in a new business value of $332 million, up 9% in local currency. This value was driven by volume growth in Spain and Latin America and improved margins in Farmers, U.K., Ireland and Australia. Business operating profit of 641 million decreased by 17% in dollar terms, and only 5% in local currency.

The half year result was adversely affected by the ongoing weakness in the investment markets, partially compensated by a reduction in U.K. policyholder tax reported already at the first quarter, and by refinement of assumptions and methodology impacting the amortization of intangibles. Overall, the half year result includes a net one-off positive impact of roughly $70 million.

Now turning to page 16, we see more details on the Global Life new business volumes. Bank distribution continues to be the main growth driver, principally from the acquisitions in Spain. The growth in both Banco Sabadell and Caixa Sabadell continues to exceed our business plan expectations.

The Corporate Life and Pension pillar increased 43% in local currency terms, driven by strong sales of protection business to international groups and from local protection business sold in Ireland, Latin America and the U.K.

The IFA/Brokers pillar increased by 1% in local currency, despite tough market conditions. Growth was supported by the U.K., driven from successful pension sales and an increase in our broker relationship managers. For both our Agents and International/Expatriates pillar, many territories continue to be resilient in the economic conditions. However, our Hong Kong business, both domestic and the international expat business were significantly affected by a fall in consumer appetite for unit-linked insurance products.

Now turning to page 17 and the embedded value results for our Life business. We continue to calculate our embedded value on a market-consistent basis. Because of market disruption in December 2008, we used average volatilities at the year end to measure the cost of financial options and guarantees. As markets have normalized, we have reverted to spot volatilities for the half year.

In addition, we have replaced the cost of non-market risk based on European embedded value principle standards with the more sophisticated cost of residual non-hedgeable risks, in line with MCEV principles. We have also aligned our calculation of frictional costs, so that it reflects required capital rather than available capital. The impact of these methodological changes is plus $170 million. These changes position us to make the final minor changes to disclosure by the year end to be fully compliant with MCEV principles.

Embedded value operating profit increased by 8% to $962 million, representing an annualized operating return on embedded value of 13% for the half year. This reflects the continued strength in new business value as well as the effects of the MCEV changes I just referred to. The negative economic variance of $273 million was largely driven by the effect of investment markets, particular in the U.K.

Now turning to Farmers Management Services. The gross management result has increased by 6%, driven by two factors. Firstly, management fees are up 4%, reflecting the underlying premium growth at the exchanges, to which I will come to in a minute. Secondly, corresponding management expenses are up only 2% driven by our expense initiatives. As a result, the margin on gross – on premiums increased by 20 basis points to 7.3%.

Looking at the business operating profit at the bottom of the slide, it increased by 4% to $643 million. The increased management results was partially offset by lower investment income, largely as a result of higher dividend and cash transfers to the group, which lowered the average investment base.

With that, let's move to the performance of the Farmers Reinsurance on the next slide, number 19. There are two factors driving the $2 billion increase in the gross written premium of Farmers Re. Firstly, the increase from 5 to 25% in the All Lines Quota Share Reinsurance Treaty in September last year. Secondly, the increase from 25 to 37.5%, which was effective from 30th June, generating a gross written premium portfolio transfer of 700 million.

This transfer has not affected earned premium or profit in the first half year. This portfolio transfer is only in respect of the 12.5 percentage point uplift on the existing business of the exchanges and not the business bought from AIG, which will be accounted for from third quarter onwards. The loss ratio of 70.1% was 1.8 points better than the first half year last year, despite a higher level of catastrophes from the hailstorms already reported in the first quarter.

Moving on to the exchange results, the Farmers exchanges, which we manage but do not own, have maintained their strong growth track record, which started back in 2006. They continue the transfer of the small business portfolio from North America Commercial, started in June 2008, which added 300 million in premium.

Excluding the small business transfer, the exchanges achieved largely a flat top line overall in an overall contracting market. The adjusted combined ratio is 92.1%, 4.9 percentage points better than half year 2008. 1.5 points of this are due to lower catastrophe experience and the balance is driven by price increases, earning through and improving loss trends on the motor book.

As to our 2008, the exchanges have continued to lead the market in 2009 by taking rate increases of 4% overall. Net surplus increased by $95 million, excluding the effect of the portfolio transfer due to our Quota Share uplift, which would give another $90 million increase, although this will be offset in the third quarter by the effect of the AIG transaction. Until the full effects of the acquisitions are taking into the exchanges books, there will be some volatility around the published surplus ratio.

Now let me update you on the acquisitions of AIG's Personal Auto Group. As announced, we closed the transaction on July 1, 2009, with slightly updated terms. We reduced the initial Quota Share Reinsurance Treaty to 37.5 instead of 40% and the capital note to 200 million instead of 400 million.

As you can see, AIG Personal Auto Group wrote over $1.3 billion of premium during the first half of 2009, 80% of which was from the direct channel. The AIG book of business has experienced lower retention and new business, but if you take a look at the underlying performance, the combined ratio continues to improve, due to expense and underwriting actions undertaken.

Let's now look at the integration status. The integration planning started quickly after the April deal signing, particularly in the areas of finance and shared services. Since the deal closed, detailed business and functional work-streams have commenced. These work-streams are focused towards addressing areas of business and expense synergies as well as strategic planning and execution of cross-selling with Farmers' exclusive agents. While we expect a certain amount of restructuring activities to result in charges primarily in the third and fourth quarter of 2009, this acquisition remains on track to achieve earrings per share accretion in the first 12 months.

Turning now to look at the performance of other operating and non-core businesses on the next slide. Other operating businesses include the operations previously described as corporate functions, as well as our banking operations. As we reported previously, there was a gain of $52 million in the first quarter on buying back some subordinated debt. This – in addition interest charges were lower in 2009 on short-term borrowings.

On the banking side, increased loan provisions explained the profit reduction of $63 million. The non-core business segment has shown the most volatility from financial markets, with approximately $300 million being charged to P&L through operating profit in the first quarter and the recovery of $243 million largely reversing that position in the second quarter.

Looking at the specific components, in Centre, the spread mismatch suffered in previous quarters reduced in the second quarter and Centre achieved a profit of $57 million for the first six months. In centrally managed business, financial market recoveries in the second quarter were offset by a strengthening of reserves in the U.S. run-off life business.

Looking now at the performance of our group investments on Slide 24. Net investment income decreased by 14% in dollar terms, but this was a decrease of 4% in local currency, driven by lower dividends on equities and reinvestment at lower interest rates. Net capital losses for P&L were $1.3 billion; of this, the second quarter charge was about 300 million, largely driven by impairments. You can find further details in the appendix on Page 55.

As a result, net investment returns for P&L was a positive 1.3% in the first six months. Changes in unrealized losses on investments included in equity were another positive of 600 million, so that total investment return, not annualized, amounted to 1.6% for this period, a strong result taking into account that government bonds lost in value due to rate movements. The key principles of Zurich's disciplined investment approach are unchanged and you can find further details in the appendix as usual.

Our equity exposure is well-controlled and amounted to 2.8% at the end of June, taking into account our hedging programs, which protect about 12% of our equity exposure. As equity markets have recovered in the second quarter, equities have increased in value by about half a billion, but more to that in just a minute.

Looking at the aging of our unrealized losses on common stocks in light of our impairment policy, in the very hypothetical case that all stock prices were frozen at June 30, 2009 position, we would expect further impact on common stocks to reduce net income by about $150 million in the third quarter 2009, after policyholder-shareholder split in Texas. In light of current market conditions we have referred to back to our proven long-term strategic asset allocation.

With that, let me comment on our unrealized losses in shareholders equity. Given that unrealized capital gains and losses continued to be an important driver, we have included this slide again this quarter. The half year unrealized gains included in shareholders' equity of $600 million is made up of a second quarter gain of 2 billion, which is – more than offsets the losses of the first quarter.

As you would expect in the market conditions during the second quarter, unrealized gains accrued on both debt and equity securities. Of the total 1.4 billion gains on debt in the second quarter, roughly 1.7 billion were on corporate bonds and another 400 million on asset-backed securities, largely as a result of tightening credit spreads.

These gains were partially offset by unrealized losses on government bonds of 700 million, driven by higher interest rates on longer maturities particular in U.S. dollars. In addition, a recovering equity market reduced losses by another $500 million on our common stock investments.

With that, let me comment on the movement on shareholders equity. Shareholders' equity at $25.2 billion is $3.1 billion or 16% up on the 2008 year end number. Net income attributable to shareholders of 1.3 billion was net of an effective tax rate of 24.7%.

So a $700 million increase in unrealized investment losses in the first quarter was more than reversed in the second quarter, giving rise to a net unrealized gain of 629 million year-to-date, net of tax, policyholder and other allocations. Translation adjustment also reversed between quarters and increased equity by another $889 million for the six months, predominantly driven by sterling recovery. The actuarial losses on pension plans decreased largely from movement in discount rates. These are based on long-dated AA corporate bond yields, which increased.

The capital movements in the quarter largely matched out with the total issue of shares in the quarter of $1.2 billion and dividends paid of 1.4 billion. Looking at the movement in Swiss Franc, book value per share increased 11% in the six months to 186 francs.

With that, let's have a look at our capital position on the next slide. Our Solvency 1 ratio has improved by 23 points to 180% in the second quarter. This includes the equity increase of $1.1 billion in April. It also takes in the full 2009 expected effect of the Farmers Quota Share increase to 37% and of the 200 million hybrid issue, although a number of these components were not be booked until the third and fourth quarter.

As you know, there is much variability in the components of Solvency 1 calculations throughout Europe. We are mark-to-market our bond portfolio, which reduces the ratio by about 13 percentages points. In addition, we calculate our solvency net of general insurance deferred acquisition costs, which accounts for another 24 percentage points.

Moving on to economic solvency at the bottom part of the slide. Including risk efficiency actions already taken, the six months' profits, capital actions and economic effect in the half year as well as committed items for the second half, our economic solvency level recovered during the first half to 124% on our internal double AA calibration.

Finally, as in previous quarters, our numbers have no allowance for liquidity premiums allowing, for example, for 100 basis point liquidity premium, would increase the economic solvency by 80 percentage points.

Moving on to the next slide. As you will have seen, we tendered for the buyback of about 730 million of subordinated debt and subsequently issued €425 million of new subordinated debt. Taken together, this transaction will give us net benefits in profit, capital structure and solvency. The major benefit is to have generated a profit net of expenses and future increases in paid interest charges of over $120 million. The capital gain will be booked in the third quarter.

So let me summarize. Our strategy of managing our risks, particularly underwriting investment risk in a balanced way, has allowed us to continue to perform at good levels of profitability throughout the crisis. Our operating businesses remain sound with good performances in difficult markets, achieving selected growth in those areas where we wanted to go.

As financial market volatility recedes, the results of recovering and our BOP after tax ROE is back above target. However, we have not relaxed on the financial market crisis and we continue to manage those things we can control to contain the risk and protect the capital base.

The capital base and solvency have been considerably strengthened by the actions we have taken and the recovery of the investment market. But keep in mind that the market movements taking over the whole six months period were largely flat. Subsequently, the strong recovery in July has generated a real year-to-date uplift.

In our core businesses, the General Insurance combined ratio was supported by the increase in rates and the expense savings actions taken. Also, we saw profitable growth due to an increased rating of Farmers' contribution to the Group and good progress in executing the Life strategy.

Our task is to continue to manage our business, aiming to deliver consistent, high quality earnings and stay focused on exploiting those attractive opportunities for profitable growth which we expect to become available during today's market conditions. So we can now move on to the questions and answers session.

Okay, so we have quite a lot of people on the line, I think, as well. But we will start with some questions from the room. The normal house rules, would be please wait for the microphone if you are in the room and give your name and your organization? So where are the microphones? Okay. I'm going to reverse this and take the first call from – sorry – you've got a microphone, the one there at the back, please.

There was a Board meeting yesterday, can you tell us if a new chairman has – a new CEO has been found already? Why is it difficult to find a new CEO? And my third question is, your philosophy was always discipline, you always mentioned that. Can you tell us, how did you put in practice your philosophy in the daily business?

So this purpose of this meeting is to discuss the results, not to discuss the Board agenda. There is a separation between governance from the Board and the responsibility for CEO succession is the Board's. As I have commented on in the past, there is a process in place that the Board is following. I am confident that they will come to a conclusion and as soon as we've reached that conclusion, I'm sure they will communicate it to you.

Let me answer the third question, which I have some control over and that is how one manages the business with discipline. I think the – we learned from a very, very difficult crisis in 2001 and 2002 and I think those learnings have served us well in this period of time. And that is really to have financial discipline, operational excellence, have strict measurements, because what gets measured gets done. Centralization of key areas, particularly around finance and risk and investment management, underwriting and claims management in a business like this are key.

If you look at some of the failures in the financial services industry, they stem from perhaps a much more entrepreneurial attitude to the delegation of some of those functions out to subsidiaries. We have embedded in the culture, through the Zurich Way, holding people responsible and accountable and when they fail to be accountable and responsible, we take appropriate actions. So I think that's part of our culture.
